Hey Bianca, please meet Lucy your incredible E-Mentor we've been telling you about :smile:.  Feel free to introduce yourselves, say a little bit about what you would like to get out of the mentorship and continue chatting within this channel. :wave:

I will now be leaving the channel, but please direct message myself or penny-prospela if you have any questions. All the best for now! :slightly_smiling_face:
_@emma has left the channel_
_@emma has left the channel_
Hello! My name is Bianca and I’m 16 years old. I would like to get out of this mentorship some more knowledge about the world of technology, and to also take a look at the world of VFX

Hello Bianca, lovely to meet you. I’m Lucy and I’ve been working in the VFX industry for nearly 15 years now. I used to work at Foundry, who make software for the VFX industry including the main product I worked on, Nuke. Nuke is very widely used in the industry and is used to produce almost all of the films you see, including many past Oscar winners for best VFX. At the beginning of this year I fancied a change and moved to DNEG, one of the largest VFX houses in London, to see what it was like being closer to production. I’m now leading a team responsible for DNEG‘S in-house fur software. This has also been used on many films, recently including Avengers Endgame and the upcoming Disney+ film Togo.
I’d be happy to answer any questions you have, or tell you more about any aspect of my day-to-day work that interests you!
Wow. Your job sounds very interesting

One of the things I like most about it is that it’s very satisfying to see the results of your work on screen, even if you don’t get a credit! And I’m not artistic at all, so I love the fact that I can still contribute and enable artists to do amazing work by building technology that helps them do their jobs. It’s also very creative because you constantly need to find solutions to problems, and I enjoy working in a team who are all working towards the same goals.
Are there any areas of technology you’re particularly interested to know more about?
I mean, I’m really into AI at the moment. But I was really wondering about how long does it take for a full production to be fully edited and have all the VFX put together?
Ah ok, we’ve been using deep learning for a few small tasks and I’m sure its use will continue to grow.

As for the productions, a lot of it depends on client deadlines and how much VFX work is required. You can always make the VFX better with more time but sometimes we have to say enough is enough! We always aim for quality but it’s not always possible if the budget or timescale is too tight.
It’s a really good question though and one I’ve never really thought to ask! I will see if I can get some numbers when I’m back in the office tomorrow.
Oh alright
Never thought that there would be so many characteristics taken into account when deciding how long to spend on VFX production

So how the process works is that usually multiple VFX companies will be invited to bid for the work. Sometimes there is also a test first on a small number of shots,  and if our work is good enough we’ll get the opportunity to bid! It’s not always the case but often the company that promises to do the work most cheaply will win the bid. And that’s where the technology side comes in, because any tools or software we can develop that saves the artists time will also save money. It also makes the artists happy when we can make their work quicker and easier!
